Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Sparsity and Scarcity in High-Dimensional Point Processes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A wide variety of important applications rely upon our ability to quickly and accurately understand the physical world using a meager supply of event-based data. Such data arise when indirect observations of a physical phenomenon are collected by measuring discrete events (such as photons hitting a detector, sequence motifs appearing in a genome, packets traveling through an Internet router, neurons firing, or people interacting in a social network). The challenge here is to use extremely small numbers of random events to perform inference on the underlying high-dimensional phenomenon (e.g., the distribution of tissue in the body or the distribution of traffic in a network). In this case, conventional models of sensing and noise do not apply, and robust inference requires the development of both novel theoretical analyses and new computational methods.

Point processes model random processes in which a realization consists of a collection of isolated events distributed across space or time. This research program is aimed at the development of new theory and methods for exploiting low-dimensional or sparse models of high-dimensional signal structure using scarce point process realizations. The theoretical results facilitate characterization of fundamental performance limits, such as bounds on the error of physically realizable models of inverse problems in photon-limited imaging and the performance gap between online and batch processing of streaming data. Furthermore, the methods themselves are practical and resource-efficient in a broad range of contexts, and being used by astronomers, microscopists, social scientists, and geneticists.
Underlying these methods are techniques at the intersection of statistical signal processing, learning theory, sparse coding, nonlinear approximation theory, optical engineering, and optimization theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A wide variety of important applications rely upon our ability to quickly and accurately understand the physical world using a meager supply of event-based data. Such data arise when indirect observations of a physical phenomenon are collected by measuring discrete events (such as photons hitting a detector, sequence motifs appearing in a genome, packets traveling through an Internet router, neurons firing, or people interacting in a social network). The challenge here is to use extremely small numbers of random events to perform inference on the underlying high-dimensional phenomenon (e.g., the distribution of tissue in the body or the distribution of traffic in a network). In this case, conventional models of sensing and noise do not apply, and robust inference requires the development of both novel theoretical analyses and new computational methods.

This research program led to the development of new theory and methods for exploiting low-dimensional or sparse models of high-dimensional signal structure using scarce point process realizations. The theoretical results facilitate characterization of fundamental performance limits, such as bounds on the error of physically realizable models of inverse problems in photon-limited imaging and the performance gap between online and batch processing of streaming data. Furthermore, the methods themselves are practical and resource-efficient in a broad range of contexts, and being used by astronomers, microscopists, social scientists, and geneticists.

Much of the work associated with this award was foundational. Consider observing a collection of discrete events within a network that reflect how network nodes influence one another. Such data are common in spike trains recorded from biological neural networks, interactions within a social network, and a variety of other settings. Data of this form may be modeled as self-exciting point processes, in which the likelihood of future events depends on the past events. We developed methods for estimating self-excitation parameters and inferring the underlying functional network structure from self-exciting point process data. We also developed new methods for denoising and reconstructing images corrupted by Poisson noise. Poisson noise arises in the context of counting the emission or scattering of photons. In various application domains, such as astronomy and medical imaging, photons counts are low resulting in very low signal-to-noise ratio images. The advantage of our approach compared to previous methods is that it easily generalizes to inverse problem settings, which is demonstrated in the context of denoising a Poisson noisy image with missing pixels (i.e. image inpainting).

The methods we developed above are currently being applied in a variety of settings. They are being used to process signals measured by a high spectral resolution lidar system for atmospheric sensing used by the National Center for Atmospheric Research and NASA and yielding unprecedented high-resolution reconstructions from very noisy data. These results can significantly broaden the range of settings in which this lidar hardware may be useful, and we are actively collaborating with NASA and NCAR to explore this further. In addition, we have used our methods for adverse drug reaction (ADR) discovery -- the task of identifying unexpected and negative events caused by pharmaceutical products. We developed a novel model for ADR discovery from longitudinal observational data such as electronic health records (EHRs). The proposed method leverages the irregular time-stamped events in EHRs to represent the time-varying effect of various drugs on the occurrence rate of adverse events. Experimental results on a largescale cohort of real-world EHRs demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms a leading approach, multiple self-controlled case series, in identifying benchmark ADRs defined by the Observational Medical Outcomes Partnership. Finally, our methods led to new insights into supernova development through analysis of X-ray expansion measurements that illuminate the origin of radio asymmetry.
